case_vignette: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an increasingly painful swelling behind her right knee for the past 2 months. During this time, she has also had intermittent low-grade fever and she has been more fatigued than usual. She has not had any trauma to the knee. Over the past year, she has had occasional pain in her hands and wrists bilaterally. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. Current medications include enalapril, metformin, and glimepiride. Her mother and older brother have osteoarthritis. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm nontender mass in the right popliteal fossa that becomes prominent when the knee is extended. There is mild swelling and redness of her right knee joint.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Thank you for providing more information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider the possibility of a connective tissue disorder, such as polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) or temporal arteritis (TA), as a potential cause of your knee stiffness and pain.

PMR is a chronic inflammatory disorder that affects the muscles and joints, causing stiffness and pain. TA is a condition that affects the blood vessels in the head and neck, leading to stiffness and pain in the neck and shoulders, as well as fatigue and fever. Peripheral neuropathy is a condition where the nerves in the hands, feet, and legs are damaged, leading to symptoms such as pain, numbness, and tingling. It can be caused by a variety of factors, including diabetes, high blood pressure, and certain medications.

As you have a history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes, it is possible that peripheral neuropathy may be contributing to your knee stiffness and pain.
